reviewText:
TL;DR: Proceed to summary.

Gameplay:I would describe this game as an arcady shoot'em up.
In a top-downish view you control a vehicle freely in a set area and shoot the hell out of your enemies while crashing through buildings. You obtain objectives to progress and occasionally sidequests. If you take too long, ignoring the main objective, the game starts a 3 minutes countdown. No need to become desperate as in my experience no mission takes more than 2 minutes.

Killed enemies may drop pick-ups. Those are health / big health / machine gun upgrade (maxed with 2nd pick-up) / secondary weapon: railgun (my prefered), rocket launcher, flame thrower / ammo for secondary weapons / key cards (mission related). Pick-ups grant bonus points if your health/ammo is full, your machine gun is maxed or you already possess the same secondary weapon.

Harder foes are introduced through progress in the campaign. You need different approaches to beat them. It ranges from kill before they fire to circling around them. It also depends on which character you have chosen as the special abilities differ much.

If you die you lose any picked up upgrade. If not ending up on the wheels, the game resets your car and you won't lose anything. If you get stuck somewhere or sink in water, you will respawn, again without loss. The game has no checkpoints. Losing the last life requires to rebegin that level, nonetheless any earned XP gets accounted.

There are 9 levels and 5 different characters/vehicles you may choose from (excluding DLC, see below). Every car has another special ability which can change the playstyle a lot. Points you earn while playing are also accounted as XP towards your chosen character. By leveling up you earn upgrade points and unlock additional perk slots. You can use those points to unlock perks from 3 single-pathed skill trees: Offensive, Defensive, Tactic. Off and Def are the same for all, only their order varies. Tactic perks boost your special ability. Reaching max level every perk is unlocked.

Difficulty settings:Casual: Infinite lives, reduced score, no leveling, no upgrades, no damage streaks.
Normal: 5 lives.
Hardcore: 3 lives, increased score.(Side note: I only played on hardcore.)
It took me the first 2-3 levels to get used to the game and achieving consistently good results. It still was a challenge though. The final level is a bit tedious because it is a very long path featuring many challenges (even a few jump&run elements) until you reach the final boss.

Controls:You can view them in the main menu and while pausing the game. Unfortunately you can't remap them. Even though the game recommends a controller, I had no problems playing on keyboard & mouse. You move around with [W], [A], [S], [D]. Press [SHIFT] to drive faster in return you won't be able to fire. [CTRL] activates the handbrake so that your car won't roll by itself (down a ramp). Use [SPACE] for the special ability and [E] to switch secondary weapon (giving up the current one). Tap [TAB] to show a semi-hollow map which will be displayed in the center of your screen. It shows the locations of your current mission.

The mouse is used to move a reticle on your screen. It marks the spot you will shoot at. [Left Mouse Button] fires machineguns. [Right Mouse Button] fires secondary weapon. If you target something above (e.g. helicopter) or below (e.g. down a ramp) you, the game adapts automatically.

The default movement emulates a d-pad, giving 8 possible directions. I recommend to enable Tank Steering" as it allows you to move freely. [W] being forwards

reviewText:
Renegade Ops runs on a philosophy of being badass above all else!

It marries the movement and speed of an isometric racing game with the endless explosions of a twinstick shooter, firmly aware of its shallowness and playing it up to great effect. The over the top story of a team of ex-military personnel gone rogue when the government couldn't make the call to action is outrageous and thoroughly entertaining, existing as a conduit for one liners and to shuffle around a bunch of musclebound dudes and gals (major kudos for having as many awesome female characters as bros, and letting them keep their clothes on to boot) with the sole intention of blowing up anything everything in their path.

With how much is going on at any given time, be it the constant barrage of bullets, endless explosions, crumbling buildings and who knows what else, it's so overwhelmingly bombastic and fun that it's easy to overlook how repetitive the levels and enemies become by the end. This definitely has a lot to do with the fantastic coop, as although blowing crap up solo is all well and good, it's nothing like the raw insanity of grabbing a friend or two along for the ride. Sure, I might have seen that texture a good several hundred times already, and I swear I already blew that tank up, but there's no time to think about that because they're back again and I'm not nearly sick of watching them go boom yet!

The only thing standing in the way of you and some friends wreaking all sorts of mayhem is the obtrusive and entirely unnecessary life system, which gives you a finite number of lives to complete a mission and should you die you're out for good. I get that the developer was going for an arcade feel, but there was never an instance when this restriction ever added to the game, only ever serving as an disheartening moment of realization as my coop partner got knocked out for the rest of the mission and was left to watch from the sidelines as I attempted to clean things up.

Renegade Ops is at its core a pretty dumb game, and it knows this, but it's also an extremely enjoyable sort of stupidity that only ever asks that you come along for the ride, switch your mind off and hold down the trigger. That might have gotten grating after a few more hours, but the time I spent with Renegade Ops was nothing if not a continual series of ridiculous action movie moments that didn't care about being smart because it was having as much fun with itself as I was.

reviewText:
Renegade Ops; A name that explains itself and explains the game at the same time, an underrated little masterpiece that’s jam-packed full of chaos, anarchy, weapons of mass destruction and all in the form of cars and trucks.

To call this old-school or retro would do it something of disservice, it’s essentially more original than that. Renegade Ops takes the old classic, then moves them to a modern level with co-op, persistent character and tremendous graphics. The camera angle is familiar with a style of zooming around a large map in a distinctive style to Desert Strike, but a little more intense.

The campaign has an interesting climax to it with a dry sense of clichéd humour and cheesy one-liners as you complete primary and secondary objectives. As you play, it is liberating and anger relieving to blow-up tanks and cars, run yourself through building, and turn infantry units into road-kill.

Renegade Ops offers various ways of controlling your car through a game-pad or keyboard, whatever suits your style of gaming. Overall, it’s a great example of a really enjoyable game based on a simple idea that is executed with care and attention to detail.

Altogether, a great single player and co-op game you can play with your friends.

reviewText:
This game is neither good nor bad. It's definitely in between. I would recommend doing some homework before you consider buying it (especially at full price). If I were younger (pre-teens to teens) I would most likely be all over this game. The redundancy of simply running here, getting civilians then blowing this up can really turn a gamer off. Some gamers however, do like games where you simply make things go boom. The gameplay is actually quite decent and may pull some players in. I know the local co-op will definitely raise a few eyebrows.

The game follows a top-down format in which you drive a car. The gameplay overall isn't that bad. The left stick drives the car while the right stick shoots (shooting in the direction you are pointing). Different cars have differing abilities. Gordon Freeman (from Half-Life) is a feature character on the steam version and his ability is to dispatch 3 headcrabs which attack enemies. Roxy has the ability to deploy airstrikes which is quite effective. Armand has the ability to use shields (yay how exciting to play defense). Diz is able to literally shut down enemies with her EMP ability. Gunnar has the ability to use a heavy cannon that deals a good amount of damage (however he cannot move while using this ability). Gunnar is pretty cool but so far Roxy and Gordon and the most fun to play with (in my opinion of course)! On top of having these abilities, players are able to boost with A. This is a nice addition as going from one side of the map to another to pick up civilians or to make a time limit can be tough without this ability. The game likes to deploy weapon drops that add an additional weapon to your arsenal. Some of these weapons include a flame thrower or a limited amount of rockets that deal a decent amount of damage.

In addition to basic abilities given to characters, there is an RPG element to the game. Players can choose from three categories to upgrade their specific character : defense, offense and tactical. Each character has slightly different upgrades. In general, defense deals with upgrades such as spare parts (that spawn health pickups when your hit) or doubling up on nitro for a quick get away. In general for offense, some upgrades include starting off with consumable weapons (such as rockets or rail guns), auto-reload or ammo surplus. In general for tactical, cool-downs for specials can be reduced, things like ram-plates can be added as well as counter-shots. You need to cause some mayhem to get some ability points!

Missions generally consist of either defending or attacking certain targets while attempting to extract civilians. It's almost impossible to go off course unless they give you a secret path to follow. Some missions will have you get into a helicopter and start attacking from the air. I think it's really cool that the game attempted to mix things up a bit and give the player a different sense of control. The problem here for me is some of this becomes redundant and is a complete deterrence for my friends and I to continue playing. I'm glad they at least added the ability to drive into houses and knock them down. Adds a little more to the atmosphere.

The visuals are pretty decent. Nothing less than ordinary or extra-ordinary. The helicopter graphics I feel could have been a lot better. The sounds are decent as well and do not go over and above. The dialogue is okay but can get corny at times.

Overall, it's not a bad game. I have tolerance for a lot of games but most friends I have played local with neither dislike or like the game. More dislike than like the game. I will recommend it but with a big BEWARE" sign.

I even rented the game 5+ times from the local video store until I saw it for $7 in a pawnshop and had my tiny mind blown that so much awesome could be had for a few weeks worth of lawn mowing money.

I like to think of Renegade Ops as the spiritual successor to Jackal.  The visuals are beautiful, and the way that bad guys explode is top notch.  I don't have a beefy PC by any means, but no matter the number of explosions and guys on my screen, the game never seemed to slow down and allowed the chaos to continue unabated.  In my opinion, the default controls using an xBox 360 controller are darn near perfect.  My one gripe with the game is sometimes I seemed to get stuck in a corner for a bit, but that happened only a handful of times and I was always able to wriggle out.

The story is basically a mid-80s action movie and very over the top.  But, it is over the top in a way that works and has a very solid action comic-book feel.

Play this game!  Better yet, get some buddies and play co-op!

reviewText:
Renegade Ops; A name that explains itself and explains the game at the same time, an underrated little masterpiece that’s jam-packed full of chaos, anarchy, weapons of mass destruction and all in the form of cars and trucks.

To call this old-school or retro would do it something of disservice, it’s essentially more original than that. Renegade Ops takes the old classic, then moves them to a modern level with co-op, persistent character and tremendous graphics. The camera angle is familiar with a style of zooming around a large map in a distinctive style to Desert Strike, but a little more intense.

The campaign has an interesting climax to it with a dry sense of clichéd humour and cheesy one-liners as you complete primary and secondary objectives. As you play, it is liberating and anger relieving to blow-up tanks and cars, run yourself through building, and turn infantry units into road-kill.

Renegade Ops offers various ways of controlling your car through a game-pad or keyboard, whatever suits your style of gaming. Overall, it’s a great example of a really enjoyable game based on a simple idea that is executed with care and attention to detail.

Altogether, a great single player and co-op game you can play with your friends.

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Top down car shooter with a cheesy story but fun gameplay. You should definitely use a controller for this game instead of keyboard & mouse.

You play one of the Renegades, a kind of special ops team under the command of General Bryant who is trying to stop the evil Inferno from launching missiles at innocent people and generally causing chaos. The story is told in motion comic style, and the dialogue is like an 80’s action movie with everyone trying to act/talk macho, but it’s fun and frames the gameplay well.

You get to choose from about 7-8 different characters, each with their own “special move” such as temporary invulnerability, heavy firepower, or airstrike. The specials are on a cooldown timer so you can’t spam them but they’re definitely must haves for some of the tougher enemies. Each character levels up independently, and while leveling up doesn’t increase your stats, you get skill points that you can use to buy passive upgrades (such as faster cooldown or better armor). Other than the special moves, the characters are generally the same and all use the same machine gun + whatever secondary weapon you find during the level.

Something to note (and it’s actually really annoying) is that even though the game is played in top down perspective, you can very easily flip your car as you’re driving around. Seriously it’s like driving a Halo warthog while viewing from the top and constantly flipping or hitting things that you don’t see very clearly. The end result is that the vehicle is much more difficult to control than it seems and if you’re playing with a keyboard & mouse you will get frustrated very fast (especially when you’re flipped on your back and a dozen guys are shooting at you).

Pros:
+Very nice graphics and huge maps full of enemies.
+Fun cheesy story with a “MUHAHAHA” type villain.
+Co-op multiplayer is available

Cons:
-The car controls can be very annoying since a lot of the areas are very close quarters (such as driving through canyons or villages).
-For someone like me who is not used to shoot’em up or bullet hell games, Renegade Ops is rather difficult. You have a limited number of lives for each mission, after which you need to start over. You can grind for levels by replaying missions, but like I said earlier your stats don’t increase, so the game doesn’t really get “easier” even if you’re max level.

Overall it’s a fun game, and if you like a challenge you should definitely give it a try.

reviewText: I can easily say that Avalanche Studios created the pinnacle of downloadable games, because Renegade Ops is the best one available on the market right now. It's certainly among my favorite games. It not only brings back memories of the good old Strike series (Desert, Jungle, Urban, etc.) in its own way, but also demonstrates what it takes to produce a top-notch, highly polished title. Everything is in the right place about this game: gameplay, controls, graphics, sounds, physics, characters, the likeable story and script, the crazy voice acting, the missions and the maps, the co-op feature... I could go on. Another great thing about it is that on Hardcore difficulty it's actually hard! After all those easy games, this one is in fact a real challenge. By the way the DLC is a great addition too. I'm surprised though that it is so aggressively discounted everywhere. But no matter the price, Renegade Ops is totally worth your time. You're a fool if you skip this game. Buy it and enjoy!

reviewText:
Renegade Ops is a 4 players co-op dual stick vehicular action shooter where players are given a choice of vehicles and is played from a top down perspective.

Vehicle handling is very smooth and the combat is fast and explosive. A gamepad is highly recommended tho. The visuals look very impressive with lots of details. Music and sound are equally good. It also features a level progression in which you can earn EXP Points to enhance your vehicle.

Downsides, the main campaign is very short at only 5 hours across 9 missions. The Coldstrike DLC adds only 2 more missions and felt that it should've have been in the main game itself. There are no checkpoints per mission and with the limited amount of lives given, it can be frustrating when you die. Also, unless you have a native XBox360 PC Controller, you will need to download a special driver for use with other gamepads.

Overall Rating: 7.5 / 10
A very entertaining albeit short game that action fans will enjoy. Don't miss it.

reviewText:
It's loud. It's heavy. It's full on action from start to finish!
Let me just start this by saying I don't like arcade shooters (I am into 4X and RTS at the moment) - and I thought this was going to stay on my HD for only a few minutes - how naive.
It is a twin stick top-down shooter, the graphics are quite nice, apart from the occasional fire effects that don't look a bit squarish. Controls, as long as you are using an gamepad, are great - some people are complaining about responsiveness, but to me the physics are spot on - not a simulation, but the cars feel like real cars.
Story is told via comic-style cut scenes and they are great - the story is absurd, but that's really what it is all about - bad guy wants to destroy the world, and you go out to kill him. The cutscenes really remind me of some very old aquaman/ironman/thor cartoons I used to watch when I was a kid.
The game itself brings me back to the arcades I used to go to in the 80's and the games I used to play - crazy stunts, powerups, some timed missions (don't worry they are very doable) and lots (I mean lots) of explosions.

HIghly recommended.

reviewText:
Renegade Ops is an all-out shoot 'em up from the old arcade days where little plot, but massive carnage ruled the day. At it's heart, you control one of a number of vehicles (mainly jeep types) that plough through waves of enemies lead by an evil head honcho called Inferno. Upgrades are picked up along the way - each helping you to progress through the campaign.

Multiplayer is offered to too, so you're not going in alone and overall, RO is a great diversion from much more serious game types. I would strongly recommend a 360 pad for this game as it's much better suited than K&M for inputs.

The only nagging issue I have with the game is that at certain stages, the game suddenly decides that you have 3mins for example to complete the objective at hand. Often, this is not long enough - and tied-in with little in the way of a saved game feature - means that many frustrating replays can be had.

Still, it's a very good blaster. Well worth adding to anyone's Steam Library. 8.5/10

reviewText:
I've played a lot of top down action/shooters and those in my Steam library are only a small part of all the TD games I've enjoyed so far.

But Renegade Ops seems to be something else.

I really liked this game from the moment I've first seen it. Awesome graphics, nice sound effects, cool level design and an entire world of destruction.

But when I got the game and tried playing it...

Sure' it still has those things that made me wanna buy it and for me they looked even better than in the trailer.

Unfortunatelly this game has one HUGE issue - the controls.

When you start the game you're told that this game plays better with a gamepad. I ignored that and decided to give it a try with the mouse & keyboard. The result was a hour of frustration that made me wanna throw my display off the window.

The controls are super sensitive and you almost never seem to get the right way to tap to make the truck go where you want it so you'll basically drive like a drunk man or a snake in the sand.

And since you can get your truck stuck in all sorts of places (between a wall and a building for an instance), you CAN'T DRIVE BACKWARDS so you'll have to struggle to get out.

Moreover, since the enemy troops and trucks are stationed between buildings' you'll have a hard time killing them without dying since, as I said, steering is a pain in the...neck. So eventually you'll end up dead not because you can't get avoid the enemy fire.

So after trying 3 keyboards, thinking my keyboard is way too sensitive, and a painful keyboard experience, I switched to controller. I tried using 2 controllers, one of them being an Xbox 360 gamepad.

While it was a little better the problems were still there. Impossible steering and direction and no reverse.

To avoid dying I decided to play on Casual, something I never did with any game I've played EVER. Everything was OK (except of course you can't level up on Casual) - the truck seemed to be tougher and enemies less efficient so I managed to get to the part where you are given a helicopter.

And here I encountered the first bug TWICE in a row. On Normal and Hardcore you have to shoot the container to reveal the helicopter and to get it. However, on Casual I was already in the helicopter when it shipped in, yet my objective was to retrieve the package. Of course this was impossible so I failed the mission. And instead of respawning as if I died, I lost the game so I had to start all over again. And second time, same problem.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=355949809

To sum it up, I've played about 3 hours (it seems my Steam progress changed from about ~150 minutes to 50 minutes after my last attempt to play this game) and I still haven't finished the first mission. And since I cannot save, I must start all over again and again and again and...

So NO. It has the WORST control system I've encountered in my life. And I've played hundreds pf games. I'll most likely finish it someday but it's hard to get this game a good review.

STAY AWAY (unless you like playing on casual). 6/10 (Because I like the graphics and sound effects and because someone actually worked in that team :X )

reviewText: Remember that old top-down vehicle shooter called Jackal on the NES? Well, I can easily call this Jackal^2. While not related to it in any way (as far as I know), Renegade Ops features concepts based on Jackal: top-down vehicle shooting, blowing stuff up, rescuing civilians... blowing stuff up. However, take this tip for when you first start: MAKE GOOD USE OF YOUR SUBWEAPON AND ABILITY. Maybe if you're enough of a badass, you can get by with shooting alone, but you'll probably want to use your subweapon, whether rockets or countermeasures, and your special ability, which is dependant on which character you select (speaking of characters, you can play as Gordon Freeman from HL2, exclusive to the PC version). However, you'll have to deal somewhat bad voice acting as well as a very bare-bones options menu (although the game looks great and runs well on my rig). A game that i'd recommend to anyone who likes blowing stuff up.

reviewText: I remember playing Jackal in the arcades.  You run around in a jeep, shooting stuff, and rescuing prisoners of war.  Renegade Ops is an updated version of that game with graphics, music, and comic book style cut scenes.  This isn't a bad thing.  Renegade Ops takes a simple formula and makes a decent game.  One problem it has though, is the missions have a time limit.  You will be having fun blowing stuff up, and suddenly have to abandon that to complete the mission in 3 minutes or less.  The biggest problem is the controls.  The game is compatible with an X-Box 360 controller, but I don't have one.  You can play it with a keyboard and mouse; but controlling your vehicle is difficult.  I managed to program my controller for the game, but aiming with the second stick was also difficult.  In the end, I had to drive the vehicle with the controller, while shooting with the mouse.  This wasn't too big of a deal, but I want to try it with an X-Box 360 controller to see if I can have better results.  Renegade Ops was definitely worth the $3.00 I paid, but certainly isn't worth full price.  But it is fun and a great timewaster.

but it didn't take very long to get a feel for it. Personally I find that performing seemingly skillful fast & smooth drifts and turns to avoid oncoming rockets and mortars and whatever the like whilst simultaneously shooting the enemy is the most satisfying part about this game.
Though the game will always say "a controller is preferred" or whatever when starting the game up I think it all just comes down to preference with this game since they both work. Playing with a controller makes driving a lot more smoother and satisfying however your aim in shooting is merely reliant on where the right thumbstick is pointed. On a keyboard & mouse there's a little bet less control when driving but aiming to fire should be significantly more precise thanks to the crosshair you move around with the mouse.

You get a choice of some characters with pre-selected vehicles to use before any mission. Everyone uses the exact same standard machine gun that can be upgraded to a maximum of 4 (or 3 I wasn't counting) that can be fired simultaneously. reviewText:
In this extremely annoying top-down shooter your drive an armored vehicle through a series of levels, plowing through buildings and blowing up waves of enemies on the way. The problems with this concept are obvious from the first minutes: first of all, your field of view is very limited due to the perspective. This means it's difficult to drive at speed, you're constantly taking fire from off-screen and you have to keep shooting at the edge of the screen in anticipation of enemies. With all the explosions and chaos it's especially difficult to spot and dodge enemy missiles, as they get covered up by the completely ineffective enemy machine gun fire. The whole concept feels archaic and I can't think of a way the game wouldn't be improved if it used a standard 3rd person camera.

Secondly, all of the main mission objectives are on a timer, which only actually appears on the screen 2.30 before time is up. I assume this was supposed to keep the pace fast, but in practice it's to easy to get caught up in optional secondary objectives and run out of time, which means replaying the whole mission. You can't explore the maps at your own pace, and the timer is infuriatingly even ticking down when you're fighting a boss. It feels like a completely pointless punishment. The same can be said of the old-fashioned lives system, which forces you to retry to whole stage should your run out of lives.

Lastly, the controls are quite imprecise with a keyboard and a mouse, plus you can't rebind them. That's a nail to the coffin for a game that requires a constant slalom amidst enemy fire. Unless you have a supreme control of your left pinkie, it's also going to be really hard to boost (left shift) while steering left with A.

All these issues make Renegade Ops a nuissance insead of light entertainment, making it hard to recommend.

reviewText:
This challenging vehicle combat shooter from top down 3d perspective (wow, it's alot) is a fantastic game that has put Avalance Studios on my radar.

The combat, the minimal campy story, the progression: everything here is simple yet satisfying, even the DLCs!

This game is very hard, but if you play it on normal or above you'll get experience points that work along with the score to improve the curious abilities each character has, and all get better with improvements in uncomplicated upgrade scheme/tree.

A timer will force you to play fast, maybe to fast for the game's good, but you can adapt if you persist. And the minimap could have been done better, but at least the pointers work well enough.

Even if you die you'll progress, Yep, you'll die a lot. Thank god it has a tank control setting, I can't seem to drive with 3d controls. Playing it with mouse and keyboard now, wich makes driving harder, but shooting more precise. If you liked shadowgrounds or Nuclear Throne this is a cool title to try.
